Triggering Event: She saw them through the gallery window, his arm draped casually around her waist as they laughed together over a painting she had poured her heart into. A familiar pang twisted in her stomach, not at their happiness, but at the absence of such casual intimacy in her own life.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I just can't believe this is happening right before me. They're actually standing here, holding hands, laughing together over that beautiful painting she made. It's so obvious how much he cares for her. But what if he doesn't really care about her? What if it’s all an act? Or worse, what if he’s just being nice to her because he feels sorry for her? Like, we met once and now they’re practically inseparable? Are they just pretending to be friends for some stupid reason? Maybe he’s doing it out of pity. Or maybe he thinks she’s hot and is using her because she’s an artist. Ugh, I feel sick to my stomach thinking about it. And the worst part is, I’m actually jealous. What if I was him? What if I could make her fall for me too? I know it sounds crazy, but I genuinely wish I could have been there to support her when she needed it most. The way he looks at her makes me want to scream. He’s so genuine with her, and I feel like I’d never be able to give her anything more than pity. But why does it hurt so much seeing them together? Is it because I know how much effort she put into that painting, and now someone else gets to enjoy it? Or is it because I’ve been feeling so alone lately? Whatever the reason, I can’t help but wonder what would happen if I were there.

Triggering Event: A parent storms into her classroom at the end of the day, complaining about a minor grading discrepancy while ignoring her other students waiting for pickup.
Generated Assessment: Oh boy was I soooo upset when my mom came into class like that today. She just stormed in and started yelling about how I gave her daughter too much homework, even though she had already missed two assignments. It really made me feel bad because I know I'm a good teacher and I try my hardest to make sure everyone has enough work. But what's crazy is that I realized after the fact that she wasn't even listening to me when I tried to explain it. Like, she would interrupt me and say "You're such an asshole" before I could finish talking. And then she would storm off. It really hurt my feelings but I figured maybe if I talked to her again tomorrow she'd listen better. So yeah, I guess my mom can be pretty mean sometimes. Oh well.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his apartment, he poured two glasses of merlot. His gaze lingered on the second glass before he placed it untouched beside her old photograph. Triggering Event:
Scenario:
After years of tending to others, she arrives home to find her husband's medication left untouched beside his empty dinner plate, the TV still blaring a game show he'd never bothered turning off. She slams the door shut behind her.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with me? I'm always so fucking worried about him. He doesn't even care that his meds are left out. Or that he hasn't called back since last night. Or that he's been avoiding our sex life because he's too busy watching fucking sports. It's like he thinks I don't notice anything when it comes to him. Like I'm just some dumbass who can't see how fucked up he's being. But why am I always the one to worry? Why does everyone else get to ignore it all while I'm the one who has to pick up the pieces? And then act like everything's fine? I swear, my whole life, I've had to be the one to hold things together for him. To make sure he doesn't fall apart before we even have the chance to break down ourselves. But no one ever says shit. They just act like I'm overreacting. That I need to "chill" and "stop worrying." Like they're not the ones who know how much I've been holding this place together with threads of hope. It's always something. Always something. Even when he tries to brush it off, telling me he's "fine," I can see right through it. There's a hidden pain there, something he won't admit. But I always end up getting stuck cleaning up after him, making sure he's okay, making sure he doesn't slip further into depression. Fuck it.

Scenario:

He woke up at 3 AM, his heart pounding like it had been set on fast-forward. The clock's digits glowed accusatory in the dark room. His mind raced through patient charts, each one a potential landmine of overlooked symptoms or delayed diagnoses. He felt a familiar tightness in his chest, a band of anxiety constricting with every rapid breath. It was another sleepless night for the 64-year-old nurse, haunted by the ghosts of patients past and present. The quiet house echoed with his silent worry, no comforting voice to calm him down or distract him from the relentless parade of what-ifs marching through his mind.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A male nurse, 37, in a committed relationship, was washing dishes after dinner when he noticed his partner had left their favorite mug unwashed. Again. He felt a familiar annoyance rise within him. It wasn't about the mug; it was the principle. They'd talked about this countless times. He scrubbed the dish harder than necessary, the clatter echoing in the quiet kitchen.

We're supposed to go out tomorrow for our anniversary, but all I can think about is how we need to make more time for each other because she's been working crazy shifts lately. But what if it isn't? What if she forgets or gets too tired from work? The thought alone makes my heart sink. And it's not even that she hasn't washed the damn mug yet. It feels like every little thing sets off these thoughts about how we're going to miss each other, and it's exhausting. Or maybe it’s just because I’m scared I won’t get enough quality time with her when she is home. Either way, I hate how this one small thing turns into such a big worry. What if she does decide to stay at work? What if she really starts to resent me because I'm always nagging her? What if she leaves me because I'm being too much? Triggering Event: The canvas lay blank, untouched by his brush in weeks. His once vibrant studio now echoed with silence save for the ticking of an ancient clock. He had hoped that time would bring inspiration, but each day that passed only deepened the despair within him. Today, as he reached for his paints, his trembling hands betrayed him, knocking over a jar filled with dried, worthless brushes. The clatter seemed to shatter something within him, and he felt tears threatening to spill over, not of sorrow, but of sheer frustration at his own artistic impotence.
Generated Assessment: What is this? I'm trying to paint here, but it's like my mind has turned into a block of stone. I've been sitting here for hours, staring at these blank canvases, and every time I pick up a brush, I feel like I’m just wasting my time. I know I used to be good, but now it feels like everything I try ends up looking terrible. And you know what really gets under my skin? My wife keeps saying things like, “Oh, maybe you’re feeling stressed,” or “Maybe you need to take some breaks.” But she doesn’t get it. She can’t understand how frustrating it is when all I want to do is create. It’s like my passion has disappeared overnight, replaced by nothing but anger and disappointment. I keep telling her, “No, no, I’m fine!” But deep down, I know it’s not true. I just wish she could see how much I struggle, even though she says I have so much talent. Yeah, right, if only she saw me actually painting... I mean, seriously, does she think I’m just messing around? Does she really believe I’m capable of such great art again? I swear, she makes it sound like I’m just having a bad week. Like, no, I haven’t been having a bad week—my entire life has been going downhill since she started talking about leaving me. Triggering Event: Awaiting her turn at the farmers market, she noticed familiar hands reaching for the same bunch of herbs she'd picked. Her ex-husband, unaware of her presence, chatted casually with the vendor. She froze, feeling a flush creep up her neck as she realized everyone nearby was watching them, whispering.

But no, he didn't even acknowledge me until it was too late, and by then, I'm already feeling so much more than just annoyance—my whole body is tense, and I can't help but think that I should have been the one approaching him first. It's really important that I assume he intentionally ignored me, because if we were still together, he would never do something like that. Right? And why should he approach me first anyway? That's not how things work between us; I'm always the one initiating conversations. This is exactly what I expected from someone like him, who thinks only about himself. What's truly essential here is that I keep telling myself these things because it makes me feel better. I need to remind myself that I deserve respect and attention, especially when I've given so much over the years.
